episode.title: Group Life & Health Insurance Company v. Royal Drug Company, Inc.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We'll hear arguments next in 952, Group Life and Health Insurance against Royal Drug.
Mr. Kaiser, you may proceed whenever you're ready.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
I represent Group Life and Health Insurance Company also known as Blue Shield of Texas.
This case involves the construction of the exemption to the antitrust laws established under the McCarran-Ferguson Act.

There is only one issue before the Court in this case and that issue is whether the statutory term business of insurance as contained in the McCarran-Ferguson Act includes a contract between and insurer and a health care provider to furnish benefits owed to the policyholders under the insurer's health care service benefit policies.
We talk only about one issue.
Blue Shield Health Care service benefit policies and in particular the prescription drug pharmacy policy which we talked about today -- a tripartite service benefit agreement.

The tripartite service benefit agreement is composed of a policy between an insurer and an insured obligating the insurer to furnish benefits to the insured in the form of goods and services as opposed to cash reimbursement.

A second feature of the tripartite service benefit agreement is that it expressly obligates the insurer to enter into a provider agreement in this instance Your Honors, a pharmacy agreement to provide the goods and services which are the risk under written or the risk assumed in the policy.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I want to be sure I understood you Mr. Kaiser.
You said that the -- you began by saying there's a tripartite situation and did you say that the contract between your client Blue Cross and --

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Blue Shield, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Blue Shield and the insured expressly provides that Blue Shield shall enter into a contract with the suppliers?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: It expressly provides that the benefits will be provided to the insured through a participating provider and it obligates the insurer to enter into participating agreements with providers.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: In other words that would be inconsistent with the insurance contract if Blue Shield itself were to go under the business of being a pharmacist and itself provided the in kind of --

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: With its policy it certainly would Your Honor.
This policy only provides that Blue Shield will contract with the provider to provide goods and services or needed goods and services in the form of prescription drugs --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Since, Blue Shield prescription couldn't have its own drugstores under the insurance policy?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: No sir, not into this policy.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Kaiser, what is the business reason either from the point of view of the insured or the insurer for requiring in the policy between those two that Blue Shield enter into an agreement with providers?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Your Honor that involves a little bit of history.
The business reason in this particular instance was that the insured and the beneficiaries insisted upon that type of policy.

The insureds under the policy that we are or under the forerunners of our policy where the domestic automobile manufacturers during a rather prolong strike in 1967 one of the major issues between the unions and the manufacturers was additional fringe benefits specifically health insurance benefits.

Out of that collective bargaining agreement between the unions and the domestic automobile manufacturers arose in agreement that the domestic automobile manufacturers would in fact provide health insurance benefits in the form of full coverage service benefit provider agreements.
Our tripartite agreement here is the end-result of that collective bargaining agreement.
Now, we're not saying we're connected with the unions or the auto manufacturers, we are saying though Your Honor that the insureds and their beneficiaries.
The insureds being the automobile manufacturers and there have been beneficiaries being their employees and the employees' families insisted upon this type of arrangement.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Why did they insist on it?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: They wanted full benefits coverage Your Honor, at a minimum cost.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But couldn't they get that sort of coverage and leave it up to the insurer to decide how he was going to go about procuring the benefits?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: That could have been done Your Honor.
However, it was insisted that provider agreements be included in this type of policy.
This entire tripartite agreement was not conceived or instigated by Blue Shield.
It was conceived and instigated by the insured and beneficiaries from the very beginning.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: In other words, the reason of the insurance contract contains that provisions that it does as largely and historic reason, it's not essential that the contract be that way that is if you're doing it now from scratch but there are historic reasons why the contract is as it is?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: The essential provisions in the policy dealing with benefits and coverage were all insisted and in fact demanded by the insureds and beneficiaries.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: As matter of historic fact?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Would it be fair to say in broader terms and you cast it that this was a response to the demand of consumers?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: No doubt about it.
No doubt about it, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Excuse me, but it wouldn't be limited to just the automobile people?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: No, sir and it has not been limited to the automobile people.
In fact, tripartite service benefit arrangements not only by Blue Shield but by many other insurance companies throughout the country or in effect and operating today.
They are in widespread use.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But there's no real reason why this be tripartite, is it, is there?
I mean no reason in rationality or normally when the insurance said benefits are in terms of money is just a bipartite agreement -- bilateral agreement?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The beneficiary receives money directly from the insurance company.
There's no reason why it shouldn't receive benefits in kind directly from the insurance company either directly of through a subsidiary, is there?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: There is really no distinction, no practical distinction to be drawn here with the way benefits are provided under our policy and the way benefits maybe provided under another traditional form of interest.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But this isn't inexorably a tripartite situation.
The logic doesn't inexorably require that it be a tripartite agreement with insurance contract itself?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Well, I might add Your Honor that tripartite service benefit agreements already distinct the feature of the health insurance industry.
That is for a number of reasons, one, the insured or the policyholder wants full coverage.
He doesn't want to worry about being reimbursed later when he is ill or a member of his family are ill they want goods and services.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Only what's full coverage when he wants money too when he has liability or accident insurance, he wants full coverage?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But that that is not necessarily tripartite he just gets the money from the insurance company.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: There is another distinctive feature of this particular type arrangement and that is that under a full coverage and when I say full coverage Your Honor I'm talking about no matter what it takes to make this person well, the insurance company will furnish those have insurance.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: It couldn't be full coverage if there is $2.00 deductible?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: I'm sorry, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: It isn't full coverage, is it?
There's a $2.00 deductible?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Now, there's a $2.00 deductible here with each prescription.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: So, that's not full coverage then is it?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
Over and above, the $2.00 deductible there is full coverage --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Well, how is this any different in the old-fashioned automobile policy in which reliability policy which insurance company agrees to provide the defense if the insured gets sued and the company then hires lawyers to represent the policyholder and provides in effect the benefit in kind to the services of the lawyer?
And therefore, enters into agreements with the lawyers to work in such a rate and be available and so forth.
Isn't that just like this?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Your Honor, I can't agree that the health insurance industry is anything at all like the casualty insurance industry because of the very peculiar nature.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: But the contractual arrangement between the liability insurance carrier and the lawyer who defense cases from time to time for the benefit of the policy holder.
Why is that any different or is it any different from an agreement between the health insurance carrier and a drug company will provide drugs?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: In as much as you're talking about that being a part of the benefits and coverage of the policy.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: There is really --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, No difference and so this case would be and if you're correct and you may well be that this is the business of insurance and then lawyers when they represent liability -- represent insureds under liability policies are equally engaged in the business for insurer.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
I don't think so.

I can't say that because for a very simple reason we say that there is a bright line standard to be drawn here and what is included in the business of insurance and the context of our case and we're talking about a provider agreement.
It does not encompass everything that an insurance company could do.
It does not encompass every contract that an insurance company could enter in to.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But it might well encompass a provider agreement when the agreement involves the provision of legal services to somebody who sued as the result of the automobile accident.
I don't see why you run away from that, that helps you, it doesn't hurt you.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Well, Your Honor I'm trying to confine and I'm not arguing with the Court.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I won't if I were you.
But you can indicate all you want but not on this basis because that's on your favor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Kaiser, you cannot distinguish between the variants and the case Justice Stevens opposed was services, here it's goods.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Goods and services, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And unless someone can distinguish between those two variants from the normal concept of insurance that's very strongly in your favor.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: No, I think that that is a normal concept of insurance as I understood.
I just don't want the Court to think that I'm coming in here arguing for the automobile casualty insurance industry when I'm not.
We believe that the health insurance industry is some what different.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, I happened to do disagree with my brother Stewart's comment that your answer that Justice Stevens' question helps you rather than hurts you and I don't see the bright line that you're talking about between an agreement on the part of and casualty insurance company with a law firm to defend its policyholders in lawsuits in which they're sued and an agreement with drugstores or pharmaceutical houses to provide drugs where the causality insured against is the need of drugs.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Your Honor, we think that the proper line is that an agreement -- a third party agreement which relates directly to the provision of benefits.

Those benefits which are under written in the policy and anything in that agreement which directly relates to the cost of those benefits to be delivered and which are under written in the policy would constitute a part of the business of insurance from McCarran-Ferguson purposes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But that Justice Stevens' questions meets everyone of the criteria you've just set forth.
The covenant on the part of casualty insured to defend the insured if he's sued as a result of an accident.
If I'm wrong if in thinking, so tell me why I'm wrong?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Your Honor, there is no service benefit policy.
I mean there is no tripartite agreement there.
There is no tripartite agreement that's been established by the insured.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So if the insured simply went ahead and as a part of the policy with the insurer when they have as a part of the policy with the insureds said, we're also going to draw up an agreement with the law firm to provide services to you and that's part of this policy then the two would be the same.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Your Honor, I think we're getting very close to prepaid legal services in many states which I have been proposed to be operated in just that fashion.
I think --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Is it not true that some forms, some policies of insurance beside replacing the casualty loss, fire or whatever also provide a fixed amount for the lawsuit profits during the period when the building or the plant or the factory is being rehabilitated and you certainly would not say that that takes that out of the business of insurance because it goes that far, would you?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Your Honor, I can't -- without knowing the full terms of a policy and the requirements of the insurer, the obligations -- the contractual obligations of the insurer, I'm not really sure that I could comment on that.
The pharmacy agreement in this particular instance though is the integral and indispensable part of the tripartite agreement.
Without it, neither the policy or the policy is not effective and without the policy then the pharmacy agreement is not effective.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Kaiser.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I'd like to go back because I'm not all clear in light of the way you started your argument.
You emphasized the fact that historically this arrangement was a result of collective bargaining and you seem to think that that was important to your case.

As I understood, the briefs that have been filed in this case, the arrangement is suppose to be beneficial to the consumer and also to Blue Shield -- your client financially beneficial in terms of lower rates to the consumer, the public, the insured.
Am I correct in understanding that's your position?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Your Honor, first of all let me and maybe I misunderstood you but we are not hinging our case upon the fact that this arose out of a collective bargaining agreement.
The essential fact there though is that this type of policy was demanded by the insureds and the beneficiaries that's how we got in to business.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Demand it because it offers this coverage at lower rates?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Precisely, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, I hadn't heard you say that.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: It offers full coverage at lower rates.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: At lower rates.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: And it guarantees the provision of benefits.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And it in a sense that protects I understood from your argument in your brief the Blue Shield Company and similar insures from the hazard of perhaps higher charges by pharmaceutical retailer outlets around the state.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: One of the principle policies behind the enactment of the McCarran-Ferguson Act was that insurance companies be able to maintain themselves, manage their own business subject to regulation by the states and that they'll be able to managing their business.
More fully assess their risks and provide solvency for their policy over us.
This provides the reliability that the insurance company must have.

That is one of the reasons for the pharmacy agreement because it does in fact assist Blue Shield in controlling the cost of the risks that it has assumed, it controls the magnitude of the risk so to speak.
And in such a situation as here where we have a full benefits coverage policy open-ended, there is no limit to this policy.
It's essential --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And for all of these, would you have thought Blue Shield would wanted this without regard to any pressure from labor unions?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: I'm sorry Your Honor, I didn't understand.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I said for all of the economic reasons I would've thought Blue Shield as a business operation saving the public would want it this sort of contract without regard to any pressure from a labor union.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Your Honor, this tripartite benefit arrangement polices have been in effect since the early 1930's.
They were an outgrowth of the depression when people couldn't get adequate health care service at a reasonable cost.
It initially started out with three party arrangements between the insurer and hospitals and the insured.
By 1940, these three party arrangements had increased to where they had 4 million subscribers across the United States.
This is not something new.
Subsequent to that, insurers began to enter into three party arrangements for the precise reasons that we have for with the positions to provide physician services to the insured.

In 1944, during the joint Senate House debates on the passage of the McCarran-Ferguson exemption, Attorney General Biddle made an express comment referring to the tripartite in nature of these service benefit policies and in his comment he said, that the insurance or the policy that they were talking about -- the arrangements that they were talking about during the discussion fits put one word in that perfectly.
He said, that word is the business or is insurance.
Attorney General Biddle was referring there to a company called Group Health who had physicians on its staff and it agreed with its policyholders to provide hospital services.
So, this is nothing new Your Honor just as you said but the pharmacy arrangement portion of it is relatively new.
It was in -- became effective in 1969.

Tripartite arrangements though have been around since 19 -- the early 1930's, Your Honors, we believe that under the plain meaning of the statute, the statutory construction in this Court's two prior decisions that clearly pharmacy agreements come within the business of insurance.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Does last terms Paul case have any bearing on this case?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Your Honor, the St. Paul versus Barry case dealt with the three --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: St. Paul Insurance.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Portion of the statute, the boycott exception.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Boycott Exception.
So, it really doesn't have any bearing.
It doesn't have direct bearing?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: It has no direct barring but it does has some barring that I think it's very beneficial and that this Court said in St. Paul versus Barry that there is no indication in the legislative history of the Act that Congress intended to define the business of insurance in a manner inconsistent with its ordinary meaning or customary understanding that being the state of the industry at the time of the Act's passage.
And as I just related the state of the industry at the time of the Act's passage was that tripartite health service benefit arrangements were flourishing.
They were well-known to the public.
They were known to Congress and in fact brought the Congress' attention by Attorney General Biddle.
With respect to the meaning of the statute, we see some very broad words, “business of insurance” and every person engaged therein.
There is no indication in the statute that Congress intended to limit the meaning of the term “business of insurance” even though during the Senate House debates in the subcommittee meeting.
There were numerous suggestions that the McCarran-Ferguson Act be limited severely.
It would suggest about --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: May I ask about the words “every person engaged therein” is it your position that those words grant an exemption to the pharmacies?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: No, Your Honor, we're not saying that the pharmacies are exempt.
It is our position that the pharmacy agreement constitutes a part of the business of insured and as exempt.
Therefore, both signatories to that agreement must be exempt or we disrate the purpose of the Act.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Does that mean that if the pharmacy hold a trade association or similar meeting and say, “We'd like to increase by 15% the price of drugs on our schedule with this Blue Shield policy is that that meeting would be exempt and they implement it by then going around to the insurance company and say, “we want 15% more”, and you renegotiate the agreement with the group as a whole and come out with a higher drug price, is that exempt or is it not?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: As I understand your question if there was collaboration among the pharmacies and then they went in the insurance.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: If there are persons engaged in the “business of insurance” is my question.
You say they're not persons engaged in the business of insurance so.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: We're saying that the pharmacy agreement constitutes the business of insurance and in order to effectuate the purpose of the Act both signatories to the agreement must be exempt.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Well, then the other signatories exempt in so far as a collaborate with one another in determining what -- how to negotiate with Blue Shield about the price schedule.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Your Honor, it would be our position and if the signatories collaborated among themselves went to the insurance said, “We want a 25% increase in the dispensing fee which you prepared to offer.”
If that --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: No, not the dispensing fee.
I'm not talking about the dispensing fee.
I'm talking about the drug price, the price schedule.
You have a price schedule I take it with chapters agreements on --

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: No, Your Honor there is a formula -- a reimbursement formula for the pharmacist.
The pharmacist receives $2.00 from the insured.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: We pay him a dispensing fee.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, I'm sorry the dispensing is --

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Plus, the acquisition cost of the drug.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: That is the formula which is reimbursed.
However, back to your question, Your Honor.
If the pharmacist went to Blue Shield and said, “We want to readjust the formula and we want more money.”
And if that was ultimately agreed upon and incorporated into the pharmacy agreement which is a part of the business of insurance and therefore exempt.
We don't believe that that would be an actionable collaboration between the pharmacists.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What about the action of the pharmacy trade association that Justice Stevens postulated their own action independent to whatever success they -- whatever agreements they had with the insurance company?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Your Honor, we believe that if it --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You don't mean that their action in agreeing to fix prices would be completely immune when you're just talking about all the drug companies.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: I'm not really sure that I understand your question, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, you postulated that a group of the drug suppliers got together and entered what amount and I took it to be a price-fixing agreement.
Now, if it stopped right there, isn't that a violation?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: If it stopped right there before they got to Blue Cross, it probably would Your Honor.
I mean Blue Shield, I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Blue Shield is not the part of that consortium at that stage.
Now, Blue Shield might conceivably have to yield to it ultimately but they're not part of any agreement.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Well, Your Honor most times, these prices or the establish reimbursement formula would be establish in a competitive atmosphere.
If the pharmacists want to charge more money then Blue Shield can afford to pay in order to issue its policies at a reasonable level.

Well, then there may be some negotiation and it will come down to what each party can afford to pay or accept but the reimbursement formula or the reimbursement fee would therefore be established in a competitive atmosphere and if incorporated into the pharmacy agreement which is a part of the “business of insurance.”

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But Blue Shield itself might be a victim of that price-fixing agreement if they couldn't buy any where else but suppose it was so pervasive that it covered that whole round of suppliers.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Well, Your Honor that's -- I guess that is always possibility obviously --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: No, you will have antitrust violation and wouldn't you conceivably?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Quite possibly you would, Your Honor.
I might mention and I apologize for not doing it.
Those are not the facts of our case and in fact the facts of our case were quite to the contrary.
In our case, it is undisputed and uncontroverted that there was no collaboration, no conspiracy among the pharmacy defendants who were involved.
It was a take it or leave it offer offered by Blue Shield.
They accepted unilaterally.
We entered into bilateral contract.
In fact, the Government agrees that that does not constitute the violation of the antitrust laws but that's really beside the point when we're talking about an exemption.
We don't need to get to the merits of --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: No, the reason that's beside the point is because the exemption if it applies would cover the conduct even if you did have an antitrust violation.
So, we have to really consider whether or not the exemption covers the illegal conduct as well as the conduct which does not appear to be legal on this.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Yes sir, I understand.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: And you mentioned would be said in a competitive atmosphere but you're talking about competitions between Blue Shield and the drug companies rather than competition among the drug companies.
And here, I gather some drug companies accepted your offer and others turned it down.
So that some think that maybe if they could agree on a higher price they might come into the program.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: I think that's right Your Honor but as the Government said in its brief that the antitrust laws are or the purpose of the antitrust laws is to protect competition not competitors.
We have some that felt that they could accept what was offered by Blue Shield and we have some that felt they could not.
Therefore, they didn't enter to the pharmacy.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: And the purpose of the exemption is to protect the competitors even if there is no competition at all even if there is collaboration.

In your point as I understand it and I think you're forth right on it that even if the drug companies all -- the whole market got together and agreed to try and change the economic arrangement so that they'll get 15% more out of these sales and they do now that that would be an exempt.
And if they ultimately and if Blue Shield ultimately signed up with them then it would be exempt?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Yes, if there was incorporated in the pharmacy agreement, so our position that the pharmacy agreement constituting a part of the “business of insurance” that that would be exempt.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: So that Blue Shield within effect have the power to grant the exemption if it were approved ultimately approved by the Blue Shield.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Oh, no, Your Honor.
We're talking about an exemption which we're talking only about the term “business of insurance” and --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: When it comes of “business of insurance” as soon as Blue Shield signs the contract.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Your Honor, the pharmacy agreement is the “business of insurance.”

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: I'm talking about a business price by the drug companies which ultimately Blue Shield could take or leave but ultimate if it takes it if I understand your position as soon as the insurance company signs up then that has the effect of conferring exemption on what would otherwise have been an illegal price fixing conspiracy.
That's your position, it's perfectly legitimate position but I'm just trying to make sure I understand it.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Well, I don't like the way it sounds but.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Well, you're asking for an exemption from the antitrust laws.
If there is a pure free competition you don't need an exemption.
Well, you don't have to come in and ask for an exemption if you're just talking about having nobody be liable for competing with one another.
You don't need for an exemption on that hypothesis.
You just need it when you have conduct which would otherwise violate the statute.
Otherwise, there's no point in this litigation.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Well, Your Honor I don't --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: That lawsuit here too, I understand that.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Of course and that is really --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Kaiser, suppose you have five drug manufacturers, who deliberately conspire in violation of every antitrust principle in the world to run up the price of at least all and that it put in, the insurance contract is protected?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Would we claim that to be the business of insurance?
Is that your question, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Would that be protected?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

It is our position that the business of insurance with respect to a provider agreement encompasses only those provisions which directly relate to the delivery of the goods and services under written in the contract and only those provisions which directly relate to the cost of those goods and services delivered to the insured.
As I said earlier an insurance company might put a number of non-cost related items into any of its contracts whether they are policies or --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I'm telling about based on drugs.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: No sir, I think that would be too far removed if they took the manufacturer?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you mean the fact that -- they deliberately got together and then jacked up the price of one drug, five companies in deliberate violation of antitrust laws and insurance company took that price?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Your Honor, I'm not sure I'm totally understanding are you talking about a manufacturer or a pharmacist?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I said manufacturer.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: A manufacturer, Your Honor I think a manufacturer would be too far removed to come within the scope of the exemption of the business of insurance under the situation that we have here.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Kaiser, your time maybe running a bit short.
I'm interested in knowing precisely what the Insurance Commission of Texas did with respect to these agreements.
I understood that initially it exempted them from approval but thereafter regarded their agreements are subject to all other laws applicable to the insurance business in Texas.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Your Honor, initially, the State Board of Insurance in Texas absolutely disapproved the issuance on use of the policy.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: But then it --

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Then it issued an order.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: To prevent a competitive disadvantage with a foreign insurance carrier who was carrying on the same business in Texas and permitted authorized Blue Shield to issue and use this policy in the State of Texas specifically referring to the pharmacy agreement and the fact that Blue Shield would enter into participating providers to provide dispensed drugs to the policyholders under the terms of the contract.

Later on in 1974, another policy form was submitted to the State Board of Insurance identical in content to the one that was submitted in 1969 and the State Board unequivocally approved that policy for issuance in use in the state.

Now, with respect to your question or the inference of exemption Your Honor from the Texas antitrust laws, there is a provision in the approval statutes of Texas and we do require that only policy for us to be file for approval prior to issuance or use.
But if the commissioner of insurance determines that a policy should be for reasons that are totally discretionary with him and within his regulatory capacity.
If the commissioner determines that a policy maybe issued or should be issued and use within the state then he may exempt that policy only from the approval requirement -- a very limited exemption.
Subject -- thereafter, the policy is subject to all of the regulatory authority, all of the regulatory statutes and other provisions within the State of Texas.
So, there was no exemption from regulation.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I understood you say initially that the policy had been approved and now you say that it was exempted, and I so understood the opinion of the Court of Appeals to say and I have it before me that in September 1969, the Texas Insurance Commission of Insurance issued another written order exempting the policy from the approval requirement of the Texas Code, is that correct?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Yes sir, that's exactly correct.
We're talking about two separate policies that were submitted to the State Board of Insurance.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, but what's the current status, is it approved or exempted?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: We have one policy that's being issues that is issued under an exemption order.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: And one policy that's being issued under a flat approval order by the Commissioner.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Which is the more recent?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: The 1974 policy is the more recent and it's being issued under an approval order by the Commission.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: An approval order?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: And all other laws with respect to insurance remain applicable even with respect to an exempted policy.
I understand from what C-85 said.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Yes sir, the Deputy Commissioner of Insurance testified that with respect to -- there is no difference between an exempted policy and an approved policy as it applied to state regulation.
They are regulated and identically the same manner.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Of what does that regulation consists so far as this type of insurance then?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Your Honor, it consists of the traditional forms of prior approval of policies.

The traditional forms of supervisory regulation such as continuing financial filings regulation of the internal organization of the company but more importantly in Texas, we have an unfair trade practices act which is very broad and prohibits virtually every type of an unfair trade practice that is imaginable.
It's a part of our insurance code.
In addition, the Texas antitrust laws are specifically made applicable to the business of insurance.
With the Court's permission I would like to reserve the remainder of my time for rebuttal.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well, Mr. Kaiser.
Mr. Pullen.

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
First of all, I would like to set this case in the proper pattern.
We do not here have the policy of insurance which in any way mentions the price fixing aspects about which we complain.
All the policy provides with respect to who is a participating pharmacist is that he is someone who has agreed to furnish covered drugs to Blue Shield's insured.
There is nothing said about the agreement with the pharmacy beyond that language.

And this is the policy that was exempted and this is the policy that was subsequently approved at nowhere in the process however was the pharmacy agreement considered or approved or anything done to it rather than the fact then it was mailed to Austin, to the State Board of Insurance.
They took it and they didn't send it back.
It's not marked filed, it is marked for informational purposes only.
When we took their positions of the people at the State Board, I asked them specifically, “Do you claim any jurisdiction over pharmacists?”
Their answer was, “No.”
I said, “Do you regulate this pharmacy agreement in any manner and they said, “No.”
And I said, “Why not?”
And they said, “Because it's not part of the business of insurance in Texas.”
So, we have today presented to the Court a question which is basically not the situation that the McCarran Act was designed to reach.
We have no --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Mr. Kaiser --

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Excuse me.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is that the testimony referred to on page 28 of your brief?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: I believe that it is, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Where does he say it's not part of insurance?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: I asked question, so that the record will be clear.

Is it your understanding that the State Board of Insurance under the regulatory authority granted it under the Texas Insurance Code has authority to regulate contracts between a company such as Blue Shield and an independent pharmacy?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Uh-huh.

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Answer: My personal opinion is that this particular contract that you showed me, then I said you're talking about the deposition exhibit 3, the pharmacy agreement.
He said, “Right, would be contract between an entity and a provider.”
Which would not be part of the original or full contract of insurance.
The contract would be filed with us for informational purposes which would be part of a plan of operations.
But when we get an entire plan of operation then there are certain aspects of it that we file such as the pharmacy agreement certain aspects of it that we approved.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I'm reading that but why did the Commission report to approve a contract in 1974?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: I believe if you look at the contract Your Honor and we covered this in our brief.
The contract again there refers to an agreement to supply covered drugs.
It does not say anything about the price fixing agreement of what we're talking about here.
We're talking about two things, Texas law has no provision which provides for approval of the pharmacy agreement.
It provides for approval of policy forms and the policy form here which the state has permitted to use does not include the price fixing aspect of the pharmacy agreement.

If all we had here was an agreement that was consistent with the policy, we would not be here because the issue would not have come up because all they would've ask the pharmacy is, “Will you furnish covered drugs to our insured?”
Well, obviously, they will.
What is bad about it, it goes beyond the policy terms and they knew it.
In fact, --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What if the state had chosen to regulate this contrary to your contention, would you say that you would -- should lose your case?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

I still think that that would be a situation where this Court could determine under the McCarran-Ferguson Act which is a federal statute what from McCarran-Ferguson Act purposes under federal law constitutes the “business of insurance.”

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But you say even if it constitutes the business of insurance if the state is not regulating it then and who was this person that you had on the witness stand that you were asking by these legal questions to?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: That was Mr. Ferguson who was the -- I believe the Assistant Manager of the Department of Policy Regulation.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Was he a lawyer?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
But he is the man who regulates the policy.
He is the man who actually determines what policy are approved and which are disapproved.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Was that the deposition on that testimony given prior to the 1974 approval of this policy?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: No Your Honor, it was given after the approval.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: How did he reconcile that action of the Commission if indeed that Commission did act that way with his testimony?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Well, the Commission only approves policy forms.
It does not approve or disapprove the pharmacy agreement.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: But I understood that the policy call for this agreement that we're talking about here this pharmacy agreement.

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: No Your Honor, apparently I did not make myself clear.
The only agreement to which the policy form refers is an agreement with a pharmacy that it will furnish covered drugs.
It says nothing about the price at which they will be furnished and that is our argument.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It does say some about the price that which they will be furnished to the beneficiaries to which the drugs will be furnished by the beneficiary.

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Yes, in other words -- but the only thing there Your Honor again, nothing in the policy itself refers to a price fixing agreement.
It refers --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It didn't say anything about the cost to the insurance company --

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Which in terms of the seller is the price to the insurance company?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Now, I would like to also --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, weren't they -- weren't the policyholders simply in the open market they brought drugs and paid the first $2.00 as I understand it on each proscription.
And then whatever the price was they paid the differential?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Blue Shield?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
And that's an important part of this case.
The policy provides that if an insured patronizes a participating pharmacist which is defined is someone who has agreed to furnish covered drugs.
The policyholder pays the deductible and Blue Shield pays the rest.

Now, that is not how it operates in practice but first of all to get back -- to stay on your question Your Honor if he goes to a non-participating pharmacist who has defined to someone who has not agreed to furnish covered drug.
That's the only test and price is not to think.
Then the policyholder still pays his $2.00 but it's done in a different manner.
He pays the cost to the pharmacist.
He then sends his claim to Blue Shield.
Blue Shield then deducts the $2.00 deductible but penalizes the pharmacy and only reimburses him 75% of a reasonable charge as determined by Blue Shield.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: How does -- you say that penalizes the pharmacy?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Yes sir.
Well, it penalizes the insured who in turn learned very quickly that he had better go to a Blue Shield pharmacy who signed this agreement.

I think it's extremely significant in this case that in 1975 when we took the deposition in October over 98% of the 31,000 claims a month which were filled in Texas under this type of coverage went to participating pharmacists and I think the significance of that it shows the coercive effect, it certainly shows a boycott and I think the question that was raised earlier of does the boycott exemption have anything to do with this case, I think it does very strongly because what this --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, not as it shows a boycott, I don't understand that.

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Because Your Honor what the effect of the policy is to allocate the business of Blue Shield insurers to those pharmacists who have agreed to fix prices with Blue Shield.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I agree to accept the price Blue Shield is willing to pay is what you're saying which has to be a lower price than the others want for their drugs.

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Yes sir and it's consistent --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I don't understand that to be a boycott.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Anybody can get in that participation, can't they?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor but that's not the problem.
The problem is if you don't get in, if you try and have a free market transaction with your customer Blue Shield then exerts this effort on his customer.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, we're talking about now more about the merits I suppose and about the business of insurance exemption --

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Well, we're talking about the boycott provision and the exemption Your Honor which I say is a matter that this Court should consider.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, supposing would somebody have a retail drugstore have an action against the Bank of America because the Bank of Americard, it's kind of coerces people to go to drugstores that will accept the Bank of Americard even and take 5% off their gross as a result of it?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: I'm not familiar without the Bank of Americard could work.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, any kind of credit card is going to have a certain coercive effect.

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: I think that's true Your Honor but let's look at this transaction and I think it will be very quickly demonstrated.
If pharmacist is in business to sell drugs in pharmaceuticals, a customer comes in.
He's had a prescription from his doctor that the pharmacist wants to fill and the customer wants filled.
The pharmacist fills that prescription; he gives him a bill for his normal charge for it.
Blue Shield says that we have some particular interest in that transaction even though it's a transaction in the ordinary course of the pharmacy business which occurs everyday.
They say, “You're dealing with our insured” and apparently their feeling is that they have some sort of vested interest in that insured.

And that therefore, they can determine at what price the pharmacy will sell the drug to his customer and I don't think the Court should be misled that this case in the Court's decision is going to be limited to pharmacist.
If this action if the “business of insurance” it is going to be the “business of insurance” or similar actions in every aspect of our society where insurance is written.
Home, fire insurance companies can have participating construction agreements.
Automobile company --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Getting back to the drugs.

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What other interest does Blue Shield have other than to get for the -- its customers the lowest price drugs they can get?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: I don't know that that's their interest, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, give me one other interest they have.

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: I think their interest basically is to increase the amount of money which they will retain out of the transaction.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And in the meantime they get drugs cheaper?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: That is questionable.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And that --

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: They do --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You just said so sir, you said that when they go to another place and they charge more, isn't that what you said?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: I did use that Your Honor but --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But more means more, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So, the other place is cheaper, isn't it?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: It maybe as to a Blue Shield customer and the way that it operates, I would say yes it is cheaper.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It is cheaper.

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So, the persons that's buying the drugs or the person is buying the insurance is getting cheaper drugs at a cheaper price, and that's a crime?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
I don't say that's a crime at all.
What I say is that it takes the transaction out of the competitive process.
And it allows the insurance company rather than the free market place which this Court have been very eager to protect and rightfully so it takes that transaction out of the market place transaction.
Now, following along and this with the question that in my analysis of this case I became concern about.
I said, is the insurance company -- let's reverse it.
Are they to be so to speak a target for whatever the drug is one to charge?

Well, clearly not; they have a way to protect themselves sales and they can protect themselves within what is traditionally been recognized is the insurance relationship in their contract with their insured.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Isn't there a factor of the predictability of prices that goes into the actuarial activities of the insurance company involved here?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: They must know reasonably what the exposure of risks amounts to.

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Yes Your Honor, I agree with that.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And if they're at the mercy of any one who wants to charge a higher price they can't predict the prices, can they?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: No, they can't predict the price but they can by specifying in their contract what they're going to pay predict their exposure on which their premium is based.
And they can do it much better if they did it that way because in that manner they could also cover the cost of drugs.
We have cited statistics which show the drug cost the part at which and all we get from Blue Shield is our acquisition cost of the drug.
We have shown statistics that those cost they're going up 59% if pharmacist's total drug cost -- total cost a furnishing service is only up 28%.
If they were truly concern with maximum control they would regulate the drug cost.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But the participating druggists manage to accommodate themselves to the economics, do they not?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: That is the question, Your Honor.
Many tell me they cannot continue to function and furnish competition in services --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, is there anything in the record here that would indicate that?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: There in some of the deposition testimony of some of the plaintiffs in my case, I believe you will find that Your Honor because there was inquiry about what's wrong of which you're getting and they say it's too low.
There's also a letter in the record that says the price is too low.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: On your approach to this thing although in some business they're not involved in this case, if you carried it to its logical conclusion you'd undermine the whole cooperative movement in the United States, would you not?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: I don't think so, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What produce bargain for the lowest prices and limit the areas of their purchase, do they not?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor but I think here we're looking at something into determine not the cooperative movement but the “business of insurance.”

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, they've coupled the cooperative concept with the business of insurance or made it part they say --

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Well, I would disagree with that statement.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We'll resume there at 1 o'clock counsel.
[Lunch Recess]
Counsel, you may resume.

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Thank you, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Could I ask you if in the 19 -- in the approvals or exemptions of the policy forms that you were speaking about in 1974 and was it in 1969?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Now, weren't the provider agreements attached to those forms?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: They -- as I recall Your Honor they were submitted with one of them and maybe near on this.
I think with regard to the first exemption order that the pharmacy agreement was submitted.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, submitted it was attached to the form, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And how about in 1974?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: In 1974, I do not recall.
I recall a letter in the record which is I with --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But what about was attached and the policy was approved?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: I would still say Your Honor that all that would be approved would be the policy because that's all the state has authority to approve under the specifically under statute.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Was the deposition of Paul Conner introduced in the evidence?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Your Honor, this was on a motion to dismiss the deposition is before that was before the court and this Court.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So, it is before the --

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And didn't Mr. Conner testify that this provider agreement was part of insurance subject to the jurisdiction of Commission?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: I don't think he did so too clearly and there is some debate about --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, too clearly I am --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Perhaps, we'll have to decide that when we examine it again.

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But you do recognize that he looking in a little bit different direction in Mr. Paul?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, now, you suggest that they approve only the terms of the policy?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But the Commission had before it exactly the interpretation of the insurer as to the scope of that policy and the meaning of the language of policy, did they not?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Your Honor, my reading of Mr. Ferguson's testimony was that this came in they did put it the file although they did not stamp it filed it I will just the matter which they received for informational purposes.
As I read his testimony, it is even though I may read this and examine it, I have no jurisdiction over it.
And that, I believe is what he said as the record will reflect.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, is this a question that would ultimately you said by a Supreme Court of Texas?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Was it ultimately decided?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Is this a kind of question that would ultimately be decided by the Supreme Court of Texas whether the Texas Insurance Commissioner has what your furtherance jurisdiction over this matter?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: It could be Your Honor.
I don't think for the purpose of this case it has to be.
I think because the statute is clear.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, then you're not relying on the deposition?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: No, I am relying on deposition very much so.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, do you really think that's the way you establish what might be a fairly important question to state law to have conflicting depositions of two agencies subordinates as to what they think the state law provides?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: No Your Honor, I think you have to look at the state statute and when you look at the Texas State statute when it talks about what will be filed, it is insurance policy forms.
And this is the point I'm trying to make when I first opened my argument that that's all the statute provides Texas has regulatory authority over.
There is nothing in the Texas statute and there's nothing it's been cited to this Court that shows any authority of the state to approve the pharmacy agreement.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Then you don't need the depositions from --

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: No sir, I think it helps considerably because he's the man who is enforcing the Texas law and this is how it does operate.
I would point out to the Court in answer to Justice Marshall's question before lunch about whether prices would increase.
The pharmacy dispensing fee of $2.00 was fixed in 1969.
There were no studies at that time to determine whether that was adequate.
There had been no studies since to determine whether it is adequate.
Our position is that we wish to compete.
We wish to have our prices set subject to the competitive forces.

They may increase if this agreement is held subject to the antitrust laws our competition may keep them from increasing but it would be the competitive factor in our society which would determine that.
I would like to also spend a little time talking about the type of policy we have here.
Despite the terms that counsel for Blue Shield has used, it is purely and simply an indemnity type of policy.
Page 255 (a) in the appendix which is the Michigan contract, they say Blue Shield is not a party to this drug sale.
The Walgreen contract in Texas which is the 203 of the appendix, says Blue Shield is the underwriter of insurance protection only.
On page 182 (a) of the appendix which is a form letter for Blue Shield it talks about how they will make payment.
And that basically, is what we have here.
The compensation to the pharmacy is fixed at one level for all pharmacies.
The net result of this and particularly since it stayed the same since 1969 except and this is not in the record.
I think it did go up to two and a quarter after the Fifth Circuit's decision.
It is our position that this eliminates competition in the retain sales of drugs and pharmaceuticals not only price competition but service competitions.
Our client say, “We cannot operate and compete fully.”
We cannot compete in the area of services.
We cannot compete in the area of hours.
And the test is also is a significant factor but it also shows in my opinion that that transaction and question is purely and simply a business transaction between a pharmacist and his customer.
Blue Shield goes further and say, “That customer happens to be an insured of ours.”
So, therefore Mr. Pharmacist we contend you what to charge him and we can make it stick and they can and they have.
They have entered into a conspiracy --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: When you say they can tell them, I'm not sure what you mean.
Are you talking about the participating pharmacy?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, participating pharmacy it doesn't have to participate.

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: No, Your Honor, but this is where the percentage comes in because what they do the way the program is set up with the non-participating pharmacist and the penalty that an insured suffers if he deals with a non-participating pharmacist.
It teaches that insured very quickly that if he wants to get the maximum reimbursement he has to go where the price agreement --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Pullen, tell me specifically, what's wrong with that in your view in antitrust terms?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Your Honor, in my opinion, that is a price fixing conspiracy and it is a boycott and it is a conspiracy to boycott and it's been very successful.
The figures show Blue Shield's own figures showed that 98% of their customer's business goes to the participating pharmacist.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: It's price fixing to take your terms in a sense that the participating druggist agreed to sell at a lower price.

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: At one fixed price Your Honor.
It may --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And the lower price solved ore you wouldn't be here I assume?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Well, what I was trying to say again and apparently for the second time I have not articulated it very well is that the ultimate price which their customers will find acceptable will be a price fixed by competition.
We could very well be successful in this case and then find that our customers will not pay any more than the $2.00.

And in fact, they'll pay less but nevertheless it is the competition that is important under the Sherman Act and that that is where the price fixing should be determined not by this type of agreement.
We have here an agreement, it is not been approved by any state regulatory authority.
In Michigan, Blue Shield is not an insurance company.

In fact, in the demo case which we're citing in Michigan, the Commissioner of Insurance who while he has regulatory powers, it is not insurance regulatory power tried to regulate their rates to help them on hospital utilization.
They have fought it all the way up to the Supreme Court of Michigan and they're still fighting and they say to him that, “That's not your business, that's our business.”
That's not anything that you have regulatory authority over.
In Texas, it's even clear because the statutes says what the state what the state reviews and it does not list pharmacy agreements of this type.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, we're not all concern here with the merits of the antitrust claim but merely whether or not the defendant is under the statutory exemption.

And to be under the statutory exemption the defendant, defendants rather have to be first in the business of insurance and second, not regulated by state law and third, where interstate of the merits to this extent that you whether or not you've alleged the boycott?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Within the many exemption and that's all but we're not interested in the --

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: I understand that Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Could I ask you, assuming you're right that these provider agreements are not regulated by the state, well doesn't Section 2 of the McCarran-Ferguson Act say that the Sherman Act does apply to the extent the state doesn't regulate of certain phases in the insurance business?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: That is my understanding Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So that even if you might consider for purposes of the McCarran-Ferguson Act these provider agreements to be within the contemplation of the word “insurance” but other words insurance business.
The Sherman Act to nevertheless apply in Texas if Texas didn't regulate those agreements.

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: That would be certainly my understanding.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But it doesn't have the record to regulate under its insurance commissioner; it can regulate through his antitrust laws or any other way.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But it doesn't purport to regulate them at all I gather.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: I wonder Mr. Justice Stewart is right because Section B says, it will supersede any law enacted by any state for the purpose of regulating the business of insurance.
I don't think that language covers state antitrust laws, does it?

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: I have some question about it Your Honor in looking at the McCarran Act legislative history.
The Court in my opinion was talking about affirmative acts of state regulation because they talk about agreements which the public authority has approved.
On this point, Mr. Kaiser mentioned the Texas Article 21 and 21 of the unfair labor practices.
We have shown in our brief and cited the Texas case that that would not apply to us because we have no insurance policy.
We are just selling to someone who has.
And I don't think that would apply to us.
Obviously, Blue Shield if they're going to be in court would rather be under the Texas Antitrust Act.
And we do have one and there's no question about it but it is not been one that has been used for damage suits and it is considerably less severe in the recovery to a plaintiff.
