I have some question about whether an antitrust statute which would apply on and after the fact basis and perhaps never be invoked a private plaintiff is the type of regulation that the McCarran Act is intended to.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the question is to whether it supply after the fact, the question is whether it's a law enacted by a state for the purpose of regulating the business of insurance.

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: As compared to just regulation of business in general?

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, Section 2 (b) has no such limiting language and that's the, I thought that's the exempt Section that was an issue in this case.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I've been quoting from Section 2 (b).

turn.speaker: joel_h_pullen
turn.label: Mr. Joel H. Pullen
turn.text: To continue Your Honor, the matter is not one sided.
If contracts for the sale of merchandise to people who have insurance coverage do broadly constitute the business of insurance, the situation may turn to a horrible type of thing.

For example, if one of these contracts automatically is within the business of insurance and exempts to antitrust violations could the pharmacist get together with a small insurance company acquire control over it and then say the Blue Shield, “We'll were sorry gentlemen we're dealing with this insurance company and we're not going to deal with you and we don't have a boycott because there are other people out here and they may deal with you but we're only going to service the customers of these other insurance companies.
And we're not going to give any service to your insureds and we're not going to reimburse our insureds for dealing with other people.”
I believe my time has expired.
Thank you Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well, Mr. Pullen.
Mr. Allen.

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
The issue on this case is whether Blue Shield's agreements with various pharmacists constitute the “business of insurance” within the meaning of Section 2 (b) of the McCarran-Ferguson Act.
The issue does not concern the merits of the respondent's antitrust allegations.
There's been no ruling on the merits the antitrust issues and there's been no facts developed with respect to it.

But I would stress that the out -- simply stress at the outset, the point that Mr. Justice Stevens made which was that the consequence of petitioner's position would be that even if the facts showed a conspiracy between a group of pharmacists to fix the price of prescription drugs and a use of a pharmacy agreement within insurance company to implement that conspiracy the consequence of petitioner's position would be that it would be the business of insurance and therefore exempt from antitrust laws.
But the issue presented --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Allen, I just want to be sure about this.
I know I put that example forward but is that true if the State of Texas has not specifically approved that particular arrangement?

In other words, doesn't the exemption only come into place as part of 2 (b) which says no Act of Congress shall invalidate the state law for the purpose of regulating insurance and unless you have stated provably you don't have the state law?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: Well, Mr. Justice Stevens, there are two portions to Section 2 (b) which maybe the source of some of your confusion but under either portion if a activity is not the business of insurance it makes no difference whether the state law regulates it or does not.
Our position is that the pharmacy agreements are not the business of insurance.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, let me be sure I get my confusion cleared up because I am confused.
What part of 2 (b) would grant an exemption if you have no state regulation?
You just told me that there are two parts to 2 (b) one of which was --

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: No part, excuse me, no part of 2 (b) would grant an exemption from the antitrust laws if there was no state regulation.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: Does that answer your question?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So, that then in my hypothetical, there's no exemption unless there is state regulation which authorized that particular arrangement.

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: That is true even (Voice Overlap) even if the activity is the business of insurance.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: State regulation doesn't have to authorize that just as to be state regulation?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And the language to which my brother Stevens adverted in Section 2 (b) I'd already understood as referring to none preemption prior to June 30, 1948.
And the general exempted language I thought was in the latter part of 2 (b) --

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: That's my understanding Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: After June 30 of 1948?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: That's my understanding too.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Isn't true that all the state law would have to do is purport to regulate provider agreements?
You wouldn't have to have a specific action of the state authority on a specific provider agreement?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: That's my understanding Mr. Justice White.
You would not have to ask --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And that even if the provider agreement was in violation of state law you have to leave the policing up to the state authority, it's not with the antitrust laws?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: If the provider agreements are part of the business of insurance that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: But if they were not at court --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, I understand right.

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: The issue presented by petitioner's motion to dismiss and the issue before this Court is simply whether the pharmacy agreements are part of the business of insurance --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I hate to take up all your time on my confusion but I think it is important that I understand the statutes.
So, I'm going to ask you one more question.
What is the language in the McCarran Act which grants the exemption if there is one?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: Section 2 (b).

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And read me the words that you talk about.

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: The pertinent portion I think is they provide it that after June 30, 1948 the Act of July 1819 know as a Sherman Act, and the Act known as Clayton , and the Act known as a Federal Trade Commission Act shall be applicable to the business of insurance to the extent that such business is no regulated by a state law.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And does it at anywhere say and you say by reverse implication --

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: By reverse implication that would suggest that if it were regulated by a state law those particular Acts would not apply.
The main provision of Section 2 (b) provides no Act of Congress --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I understand that.
So, you're saying that the -- in other words, it's the reverse implication of the proviso as the sole source of the exemption?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: That's my understanding although of course under our position it wouldn't make difference because under our position it's not the business of insurance.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, the words the “business of insurance” are found in that Section 2?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Alright.
I'm sorry of taking your time.

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: That's quite alright.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I would suppose the first part of 2 (b) would set aside any state law that was in conflict with the antitrust laws.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Would not be, isn't it?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: The first part of 2 (b) provides no Act of Congress shall be construed to supersede according from memory.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: Any state law enacted for the purpose of regulating insurance.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Including antitrust laws?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: Including the antitrust laws.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So, it would not apply if it serve to --

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: Supersede.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: To supersede a state law?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So, the first part of 2 (b) would give insurance business exemption from antitrust laws if --

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: That is correct Mr. Justice White.
The first part of Section 2 (b) would do so expressly.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, and why do you say it's a latter part?
Only the latter part.

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: Well, let me modify my position, it is not only the latter part.
The latter part refers specifically to the Sherman Act upon which petitioners relied for their antitrust complaint.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But the first thing --

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: The first part would include the Sherman Act as well as --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Sherman Act and every other federal law.

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: That's correct.
But the first part --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It also includes the Robinson-Patman Act the first part of 2 (b) and which is not referred to and that exempts in the proviso?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: That is correct.

But the first part would only limit the application to federal law to the extend it happened to supersede a state law designed for the purpose of regulating the business of insurance if I made myself clear.[Laughter]
In any event, we contended that the pharmacy agreements are not part of the business of insurance and our argument may be summarized as follows.
The precise scope of the business of insurance exemption is not clearly delineated and the McCarran-Ferguson Act and there maybe areas of reasonable doubt.
Although, this Court has frequently stated the principle that in areas of reasonable doubt; antitrust exemptions are to be narrowly construed and antitrust application to be favor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: That's implicit exemption, isn't it?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: No, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, this Court has applied that principle even in the case of express exemptions.
The two cases for example that we cited in our brief, Abbott Laboratories and Federal Maritime Commission versus Seatrains were case of express exemptions from the antitrust laws.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Do you think that one applies the principle of narrow construction equally to express exemptions as to imply the exemption?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: Yes, I do Your Honor.
When you're dealing with an express exemption such as the McCarran-Ferguson Act or the many other express exemptions, the principle applies that exemption is to be narrowly construed.

In any event, what the legislative history the McCarran Act does indicate is this Court has held in SEC versus Variable Annuity Company and SEC versus National Securities is first that Congress' core concern with respect to the business of insurance was the underwriting risk and the relationships between insurance companies and policyholders that concern the underwriting of risk.
And the second thing the legislative history indicates is that Congress did not intend to exempt everything an insurance company does.
Those two facts support our contention that the pharmacy agreements are not the business of insurance.
First, the pharmacy agreements are not the underwriting of risk.
They are simply contracts for the purchase of drugs and drug distribution services by Blue Shield --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What is your response to what we suggested this morning on the universal practice of public liability insurance insuring not only against the risk of ultimate judgment against the policyholder but the cost of litigation, is that --

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: My response is that that example is a good illustration of our point.

We think it would be absurd to contend that an agreement between an insurance company and a law firm concerning the supplying of legal services to the insurance company is the business of insurance in any ordinary sense.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: How about the provision in the policy itself?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: Even if it's in the policy itself it simply begs common ordinary understanding to say that an agreement between an insurance company and a law firm about how much they're going to pay per hour is the business of insurance.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Isn't also true that medicine is part of health?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: That's true too Your Honor and our argument that will follow.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That they can -- well, as the paying of the doctor's bill insurance?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: The paying of the claims to the insurer -- to the policyholder is the business of insurance and an agreement between the insurance company and somebody who provides services is we contend not the business of insurance.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Including the doctors?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: Including the doctors, including the pharmacists, there's no difference between pharmacist and doctors.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Then under the Group Health Plan it wouldn't be covered, wouldn't the insurance would because they pay the doctors?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: I'm not certain, I understanding to your point Mr. Justice Marshall --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: They pay the doctors.
The Group Health hires the doctor.

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: That's true.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So, that wouldn't be insurance then?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: The hiring of the doctors would not be the business of insurance.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: What if the --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It wouldn't be -- they wouldn't be covered by this?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: It would not be part of the business of insurance and maybe perfectly lawful.
There's no reason to suppose it's not lawful but it wouldn't be part of the business of insurance.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What if forgetting any problems of legal ethics or anything, what if an insurance company just had a stable of lawyers, its employees that it furnished under its insurance contracts to beneficiaries who were sued for liability, would those employment contracts with the lawyers pay the business of insurance?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: I think not Mr. Justice Stewart.
It's hard to see how those contracts had violated the antitrust laws but the relationship between although the question is not so clear.
I think that's an area of --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: If it's not clear, then why is it so clear that if the insurance company does the same thing with independent contracts is it all of a sudden becomes very clear?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: Well, it seems to me basis for distinction between one's dealings with ones own employees and ones dealing with outside contract.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: In each case, the insurance -- the insurer is furnishing the services and what difference has it whether so far as this exemption goes whether it does so through its employees or through independent contract?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: Well, I think as I say my first response would be that I don't think labor relation agreements between an insurance company and doctors --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But you don't make the labor relations agreements, they're employment contract, no point in giving out a fancy name.

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: Between insurance company and its doctors, my first reaction was I don't think that will be the business of insurance although I think the question there would be closer because I think there's a basis for distinction.
But the point we wish to emphasize is that at some point you have to draw the line.
Relations -- insurance companies have myriad relationships with third parties what you would call independent contractors to furnish the insurance company with good and services.
They contract with printers, they contract with lawyers, they contract with building owners.
Congress, there's no suggestion in the legislative history the Act of Congress intended and all of those kinds of relationships to be the business of insurance.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Now, you don't seriously contend that the promise to furnish to defend that person in a case of an accident is not insurance.

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: No, the promise is insurance to deliver in the pharmacy --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Alright then, I wouldn't think you would think -- if there's been an accident the companies called upon to furnish the legal services that were promised.
You wouldn't think furnishing the legal service was not insurance?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: No, I agree that that would be insurance --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And if they're going to furnish to legal service they're going to have to pay for them?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: That is correct but only in the same sense.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You wouldn't if the insurance company goes out to an independent law firm and hires them to furnish the services that were promised; the furnishing of those services is part of insurance business?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: Well, we can say no because --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You just said so.

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: The furnishing of the services to the policyholders, that's right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And but you wouldn't think that the negotiation the price at which that they were furnished was part of the insurance?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: Negotiation between the insurance company and the lawyer we would contend does not the business of insurance because there is no principle basis for distinguishing that kind of agreement between insurance company --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why not draw the line and say well, perhaps that piecemeal negotiation is one thing but a forward contract, they're sort of a supply contract in the indefinite future is something different.
You don't think that one.

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: Because the any kind of any distinction on that basis would break down.
For instance, --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Any distinction breaks down and what about the contract of purchase the paper on which the policy is written, is that part of the business of insurance?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: The contract that purchased the paper?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: On which the policy is printed.

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: We would contend it would not be and that a conspiracy between printers to fix the price of printing services which used an agreement within an insurance company to do too to implement that conspiracy is not what Congress intended to exempt from the antitrust laws.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Well, the insurance company could be a plaintiff in an antitrust lawsuit against the paper manufacturers who agreed to fix the prices.

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: Exactly, we contend it would be.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: It could be a plaintiff here.
It could be a plaintiff here against at any pharmacist to agree among themselves to fix the prices but it isn't the question here, the question is whether --

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: Under our contention -- but not on the petitioner's contention.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: No, no I think --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: He responded to that this morning.

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: But not consistently.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But the point is that now we have an agreement with them between the insurance company and the pharmacist to provide services and the question is whether or not that is the business of insurance.

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: And our response is that it is not because if it were then everything in an insurance company would do to save its own costs of services would be the business of insurance.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Of course, perhaps that's the answer.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But Mr. Kaiser --

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: But Congress did not so intend.
It's clear from this Court's decisions in Congress.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I understood Mr. Kaiser this morning when I put the question to him to say that the action of the drugs -- drug people together independent of the agreement with Blue Shield could be an antitrust violation and one of the ways that could be asserted would be for Blue Shield to sue them because they were pushing the price up; price fixing agreement.

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: That's correct Mr. Chief Justice but the distinction is important.
He makes that concession and that's perfectly true.

We agree with that but what his position necessarily entails is that if that conspiracy between the pharmacist were embodied in an agreement with an insurance company that would be the business of -- that agreement would make it all part of the business of insurance.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: It doesn't know his response to that was that would not render them.
It might be part of the business of insurance as between Blue Shield and the druggist but it wouldn't render the druggist immune from an antitrust violation for their own agreement.

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: Well, I don't understand that to be their position Your Honor.
I didn't hear him to say that this morning.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I understood that very clearly that it was his position.

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: But if that's his position what he saying is that then we can violate the antitrust laws by entering into an agreement with pharmacist --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, that's sort of exemption from the antitrust laws mean.

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: And the pharmacist would be guilty of antitrust and we would not.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, that's exactly an exemption means that you can violate, you can engage in conduct which would be violated of the antitrust laws if you didn't have an exemption.
That's exactly what his position is.

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: But what this Court has established is that the McCarran-Ferguson Act didn't intend to immunize entities that intended to immunize conduct, agreements practices --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Except that a business, the business of insurance?

turn.speaker: richard_a_allen
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Allen
turn.text: That's right.
But it doesn't matter who's engaging in it.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well, Mr. Allen.
You have some time left Mr. Kaiser.
Do you have anything further?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Thank you.

Mr. Chief Justice, if there was any confusion with our discussion earlier today it would be our position that in the event pharmacist get together and conspired to enter into a pharmacy agreement and came the Blue Shield and told us, held a gun to our head so to speak and said we're not going to enter in to this agreement with you unless you pay us a certain price and that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, what if Blue Shield joined the conspiracy?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Your Honor that if we are a victim of a conspiracy ---

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I didn't say that.
I said they are party to it.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Under those -- like we have two different circumstances under my theory --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, yes I know but I'm asking about mine now.
How about Blue Shield is party to the conspiracy?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Alright Your Honor, if Blue Shield was a party to the conspiracy --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Remember they are carrying out the business of insurance according to your view.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: It would be my initial impression right now that if the agreement was embodied into the pharmacy agreement and it is always been our position that the pharmacy agreement is immune as a part of the business of insurance.
Well, then there would be no violation.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Blue Shield would be immune?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: How about -- and but nevertheless I suppose you say the druggist --

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: For the separate conspiracy between the druggist there maybe an actionable that maybe actionable conspiracy.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But Blue Shield is at least an ordinary human experience isn't as likely to -- isn't very likely to enter into conspiracy to raise their own costs?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Not at all, Your Honor that would be totally against our own interest and the interest of our policyholders.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: So, the hypothesis is at least economically not very real?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Unless they get together to keep Blue Shield from going too low and Blue Shield gets paid off in some way?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Yes, I guess that is the possibility Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, it has been true, hasn't it in some places?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Not to my knowledge Your Honor.
I'm not familiar with anything of that nature that's ever happened.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Is the price fixing agreement have to be the fix maximum prices to be unlawful supposing it's an agreement to fix prices is much lower than anybody else can charge?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Your Honor, there's considerable dispute about that but as I read the cases of price fixing can either be to fix maximum prices or minimal price.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It may be illegal either way, would it not?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Strictly from the antitrust from an act standpoint.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So they could have a lot of group of large druggist who wanted to have a very low price in order to drive small companies out of business for example and persuaded Blue Shield to go along with it and that would normally be an antitrust violation?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Well, I'm operating my thoughts are under the theory that Blue Shield would offer this agreement to everyone; somewhat to possibly be able to accept some possibly not.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Is there any limitation now, can anyone be a participant?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Any license pharmacy in the State of Texas has been invited and is capable of becoming a participating pharmacy.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Allen to be sure that my confusion is completely cleared up, do you agree with the view that in order to qualify for the exemption under Section 2 (b) of the McCarran Act you must establish both that you're in the business of insurance and secondly that that which you claim is an exemption is regulated by state law?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
We claim that we -- it must be constitute a part of the business of insurance and the activity must be regulated by state law.
And we believe that undeniably has in this case.
Your Honor, we have talked considerably today about --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I take it that the court below did not reach the second step.
They just simply said, it's not the business of insurance.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: The Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit did not reach the second step.
However, the trial court found that it had been regulated in its words pervasively.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But the Court of Appeals didn't reach that second?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: No sir.
It said that, in view of the fact that it was finding at the pharmacy agreement did not constitute business of insurance.
It was not required to go to the second step relating to state regulation nor was it required to go to the step relating to boycott.
The business of insurance is a federal question.

There seems to have been considerable discussions today about the state's interests and whether or not the state has regulated and whether or not the state considered the matter to be the business of insurance.
While we believe --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It's true that the exemption however exist only at the exemption for the business of insurance exist only to the extent that it is regulated by state law?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So, and your opponent in part 2 I think it is what the brief asserts that this is not regulated by state law.
So, that's reason that became relevant as I understood that relevance of that argument.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Yes sir, well, I just want to make our point clear.
We're not relying upon what the state did to say that this constitutes the business of insurance.
We're relying strictly upon a federal standard.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But the federal standard upon that federal standard is that the business of insurance has to be regulated by state law?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But suppose the state says that the dealing in drugs is not an insurance function and therefore we will not regulate it.
Then, what would your position be?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: My position would still be the same Your Honor.
The business of insurance is a federal question.
If it happens to be the business of insurance but not regulated, the exemption does not attach.
Although, we do believe that federal court should give certain --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, if they said it was and they did move and it would be a very question.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: I'm sorry Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: If they said it was an insurance problem and did regulate it, it would not be a federal?
You don't go that way, do you?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: I think its still would be a federal consideration, Your Honor.
The business of insurance is a federal question to be decided by the federal courts.
We do not suggest that everything in insurance company does constitutes the business of insurance.

An insurance company may do many things in the conduct of its business which are not directly related to the furnishing of specific benefits and which are not related directly to the cost of those specific benefits.
What we are saying in our position here today is that the pharmacy agreement directly violates --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, what would some of those things be -- let's assume a company that's an insurance company nothing else --

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It's not a conglomerate or anything.
So, only in the insurance business now, what would all -- what are those many things be --

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: As the Solicitor General has said that the contracts for the purchase of paper (Voice Overlap) the buildings --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, how can that be the building of insurance?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: That I would say it would not --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: If it's in the insurance business then it has to buy paper.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Your Honor, the federal courts and this Court has said that the key is not whether or not it's in the insurance business but the business of insurance and there's a difference --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, it's in the business of insurance and then conducting at business it has to have policies?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Whether written or printed on paper and why therefore, shouldn't its purchase of paper be the business of insurance?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Because there is not a requisite relationship between the insurer and its policyholder in that situation.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, about the paper used for -- that that they send out to the policyholder to submit claims on?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: That still would not really involve the claim -- the risk --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Condition of the policy is that you file a claim on this form?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Your Honor, I think that would be too attenuated to the business of insurance to become an exempt to activity.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What about the between the insurance company and the lawyer to employees to defend the casualty case?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: I'm sorry, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Now, we're back where we started.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I want to go back where we started on the lawyer hired by the insurance company to defend the policyholder who sued under a liability policy.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Would that be the business of insurance?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: If it was an obligation contained in the policy of insurance?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The policy says, “We'll defend all claims.”

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: And if it was --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It doesn't say by lawyers or how but then they go and hire lawyers to defend the claims.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: If it is a part of the coverage and benefits provided by the policy and if it is something that is eminently related to the insured --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, I don't think I don't need any adjectives.
Yes or no, is it covered in your view or not?
Is it part of the business of insurance?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: I think it might be Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You think it might be?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You're not very confident and yet I don't see any difference between that in providing drug as I indicated earlier.
I don't understand your lack of confidence on that case in your complete confidence on this case.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Your Honor, it's the difference between that.
The conceptual difference between the two types of cases here, I agree with Your Honor's hypothesis.
I think I agree and not I think I agree but I do agree.
However, we're looking at a different type of insurance and a different type of policy here.
We're looking at one where this particular --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Supposing you pay money and you go out and borrow money from a bank to pay off a claim in dollars, is that the business of insurance?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: If the insured?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No, the company has a little short of cash so they go to the bank to raise the cash to pay off a very large claim at some catastrophe of some kind.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Your Honor, I don't believe that would constitute --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, how's that different?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Well, it does -- I believe that it would fall too far outside the relationship between the insurer and the insured.
The assumption of risk in providing a benefit --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What the insurance company needs to satisfy a claim that it's obligated and under the policy to satisfy, it's $10.00 rather than drugs.
I don't see the difference.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: I don't believe it would fall within the criteria establish by this Court in SEC versus National Securities.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The only criteria there is that it be the business of insurance.
It's kind of a question begging criteria --

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, this Court set out --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And if you buy the company.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Set out some very broad criteria in determining what constitutes the business of insurance in that case but the real nexus for what does constitute the business of insurance are matters that intimately relate to the insurer-insured relationship.

The Court also said that the type of policy which could be issued its reliability, interpretation and enforcement and other activities of insurers which relate closely to their status as reliable insurers constitute the business of insurance for McCarran purposes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Do you apply that all that language to make a big loan from a bank to pay-off a policy obligation it seems to me?

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Your Honor, there was the preceding case in 1959 of Securities and Exchange Commissioner versus Variable Annuity said, that the merger of two insurance companies even though the sale of stock or the holding of stock involved the insureds to some respect said that that was not sufficient that did not sufficiently relate to the insurer-insured relationship.
And I think your proposition of that going out and borrowing money would be more akin to the Variable Annuity case.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The real answer is, to my brother Stevens' question is that the further we take you away from this case and your theory of the less certain you get.

turn.speaker: keith_e_kaiser
turn.label: Mr. Keith E. Kaiser
turn.text: Yes sir.
Thank you very much Your Honors.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you Mr. Kaiser.
Thank you gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
